The text discusses the use of beach and pole seining as an efficient method for capturing fish in various types of aquatic habitats. This technique is most productive in relatively shallow waters with minimal obstructions where fish populations are dense, particularly for species that are less agile and unlikely to outswim the net. However, it can also capture more mobile species like adult salmon under certain circumstances.

Seining allows for the efficient sampling of large areas in a short time frame while minimizing stress or harm to captured fish. This is achieved by keeping the bunt (bottom edge) of the seine submerged and quickly transferring fish to holding containers if necessary. The cost of this fishing method varies significantly depending on factors such as the size and frequency of sampling, required gear, boats, and personnel.

Seining can be applied in various habitat types, with suitability determined by factors like bottom topography, debris accumulation, aquatic vegetation, current velocity, and depth. Sites with complex bottom structures or significant obstacles may result in net snagging or reduced fish retention, making them unsuitable for seining.

To optimize the selectivity and capture efficiency of seining, it is essential to consider several factors: habitat, water conditions (e.g., temperature, salinity), fish species, time of year and day, net design, and method. Proper study design, including pre-sampling observations and calibration studies, can help determine when seining will be effective for achieving your research objectives.

When conducting perpendicular quarter-arc set beach seining, it can be used for fish/area or fish/volume analysis. To ensure consistent measurements, mark the poles with depth increments and attach a rope of fixed length to the upper end of each pole to maintain a constant swept area width.
